Topic: Construct definition & dimensions (Capability index)
Action/Deliverable: Write a 2–3 page memo: what you did in DXC (BINA) and what 'good construct definition' looks like.
Why (for your PhD): You already practiced defining dimensions (Business & Governance Alignment, Infrastructure/Data/Tech, People/Culture, Agility/Process) — turn it into an explicit transferable skill for your PhD work.
Key refs/resources: Your DXC dimensions and definitions in the DTI deck (BINA).

Topic: Needs index concept (pressure/urgency/intent)
Action/Deliverable: Map the DXN (NUSA) idea to your PhD: 'multi-audience legitimacy pressures' as 'needs/pressure'.
Why (for your PhD): You already framed 'need & pressure' and timing urgency; this becomes a bridge to legitimacy pressures in higher education.
Key refs/resources: DXN dimensions: Need strength, Urgency, Stakeholder demand, Ambition/intent.

Topic: Instrument design: indicators & survey items
Action/Deliverable: Create a short checklist for writing survey items (clarity, single-idea, scale anchors) + examples from your index.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal includes a longitudinal survey; you can reuse your instrument-building muscle memory.
Key refs/resources: DTI deck sections on indicators and survey item lists.

Topic: Psychometrics pipeline (content/face validity → pilot → EFA/CFA → invariance)
Action/Deliverable: Document your end-to-end validation pipeline as a template for the PhD survey strand.
Why (for your PhD): Your index roadmap already includes validation steps and measurement invariance; formalizing it will speed up your PhD survey work.
Key refs/resources: DTI deck psychometric validation timeline (content/face validity, pilot, EFA/CFA, invariance).

Topic: Index weighting approaches (PCA, Entropy, AHP, DEA)
Action/Deliverable: Write a 1-page 'when to use what' note + assumptions/limitations for each method.
Why (for your PhD): Even if your PhD isn't an index, this trains you to justify operationalization and weighting/aggregation choices (important in management research).
Evidence of completion: Comparative note + example calculation in Excel/R
Key refs/resources: DTI deck lists PCA/Entropy/AHP/DEA and rationale snippets.

Topic: What counts as a contribution in management research
Action/Deliverable: Read 2–3 classic pieces on 'theoretical contribution' and write a 1-page 'contribution claim' for your project.
Why (for your PhD): Management PhD evaluation is theory contribution-first; you need to state clearly: phenomenon → gap → mechanism → contribution.
Key refs/resources: Look up: theory contribution in management (journal editorials; PhD handbook).

Topic: Paradigms & philosophy of science (positivist/interpretivist/critical, etc.)
Action/Deliverable: Make a 'stance' note: where your project sits (process/interpretive with complementary survey).
Why (for your PhD): Helps you defend method choices (process study + survey) and write the methodology chapter coherently.
Key refs/resources: Intro texts on philosophy of social science; IS research methods overviews.

Topic: Reading for theory (how to read management papers)
Action/Deliverable: Create an 'annotated reading template' (question, constructs, mechanism, boundary conditions, methods).
Why (for your PhD): You’ll process a large literature base (temporal structuring, legitimacy, GenAI/assessment) efficiently.
Key refs/resources: Use it for the first 10 papers immediately.

Topic: Academic writing in management (argument structure)
Action/Deliverable: Write a 1-page 'storyline' for your proposal: phenomenon → puzzle → theory → method → contribution.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal is already strong; this turns it into publishable framing.
Key refs/resources: Use your current abstract and RQs as starting point.

Topic: Temporal structuring (Orlikowski & Yates) — concepts & how to operationalize
Action/Deliverable: Build a concept map: rhythms, pacing, deadlines, 'what counts as progress', temporal regimes; list observable indicators in universities.
Why (for your PhD): Your project uses temporal structuring as overarching lens; you need to move from citation → analytic toolkit.
Key refs/resources: Your proposal states time is enacted through recurrent practices (temporal structuring).

Topic: Organizational legitimacy (Suchman) — pragmatic/moral/cognitive + multi-audience
Action/Deliverable: Write a 'legitimacy matrix' for students/parents/employers: what each audience values; what evidence they accept; likely conflicts.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal foregrounds multi-audience legitimacy in higher education; this matrix guides sampling and analysis.
Key refs/resources: Proposal highlights triadic audiences (students/users, parents/payers, employers/validators).

Topic: Sociomateriality (Orlikowski) — using it without 'tech as factor'
Action/Deliverable: Create a memo: what 'entanglement' means in your setting (AI tools, rubrics, LMS logs, policies, classroom practices).
Why (for your PhD): Needed to theorize why 'adding AI' reconstitutes assessment artifacts and interaction, as you argue.
Evidence of completion: 2-page sociomaterial memo + list of artifacts to collect
Key refs/resources: Proposal frames educational work as sociomaterial and entangled.

Topic: Algorithmic management & contested control (Kellogg et al.)
Action/Deliverable: Identify 3–5 'control points' in universities (proctoring, detection, AI feedback, dashboards) and potential resistance tactics.
Why (for your PhD): You link AI proctoring/detection/feedback to new control and resistance dynamics; you need concrete analytic categories.
Key refs/resources: Proposal notes AI standardizes evaluation/visibility reshaping control/resistance.

Topic: Signaling theory (Spence) applied to degrees under GenAI
Action/Deliverable: Write a 1–2 page note: what signals are at risk, what alternative signals may emerge (authentic assessment, portfolios, proctored tasks).
Why (for your PhD): Your legitimacy argument includes degrees as signals; you need to connect signal credibility to assessment redesign.
Key refs/resources: Proposal links credential trust to signaling and risk of inflated competence.

Topic: Mid-range theory & mechanisms (from process data)
Action/Deliverable: Practice: write 3 candidate mechanisms for 'fast but hollow' vs 'durable bridges' and what evidence would support each.
Why (for your PhD): Your intended output is a mid-range theory of temporal legitimacy; mechanism thinking is the core skill.
Key refs/resources: Proposal aims for mechanism-based explanation and mid-range theory.

Topic: Define and refine your new construct: Flashpoint Bridgework
Action/Deliverable: Draft a construct definition + dimensions (re-timing, re-authoring, re-legitimating) and boundary conditions.
Why (for your PhD): This is your signature contribution; it must be crisp and distinguishable from adjacent constructs.
Key refs/resources: Proposal lists bridgework visibility in re-timing/re-authoring/re-legitimating practices.

Topic: Higher education as an organizational field (governance, quality assurance, professional bodies)
Action/Deliverable: Build an annotated map of key stakeholders and institutional constraints in your target contexts (UK + emerging economy).
Why (for your PhD): Your cases sit inside a regulated field; legitimacy is shaped by accreditation, QA, and professional norms.
Evidence of completion: Stakeholder map + 1-page field note per context
Key refs/resources: Start from your triadic audience framing in the proposal.

Topic: Assessment regimes & academic integrity governance
Action/Deliverable: Collect and compare 5–10 university AI/assessment policies; code what counts as acceptable assistance, evidence, and fairness.
Why (for your PhD): Bridgework is likely visible in policy texts and enforcement practices (integrity cases).
Key refs/resources: Proposal includes institutional artifacts: policies, guidelines, rubrics, integrity cases.

Topic: Learning analytics / LMS as sociotechnical infrastructure
Action/Deliverable: Identify what 'digital traces' exist (LMS logs, submission history, feedback tools) and ethical access routes.
Why (for your PhD): Your design mentions digital traces; you’ll need to know what's realistic and how to interpret traces.
Key refs/resources: Proposal mentions LMS logs/workflow documents/anonymized assessment iterations.

Topic: Generative AI in learning: promises vs failure modes
Action/Deliverable: Create a 2-page synthesis: support (personalization/materials) vs risks (validity, ethics, 'false mastery').
Why (for your PhD): This grounds your phenomenon and helps you design interview prompts that go beyond 'cheating'.
Key refs/resources: Proposal frames GenAI as both promising and disruptive; risk of 'false mastery'.

Topic: Epistemic agency (assessment–knowledge–society link)
Action/Deliverable: Operationalize 'epistemic agency' for your study: behaviors, responsibilities, discourse markers; propose how to observe it.
Why (for your PhD): Your bridgework aims to protect/enable epistemic agency; you need an observable definition for analysis.
Key refs/resources: Proposal discusses epistemic agency at risk when cognition is outsourced.

Topic: Authentic assessment design & redesign patterns
Action/Deliverable: Compile a pattern library: in-class drafting, oral defenses, iterative drafts, reflection, portfolios, group work, etc. + pros/cons.
Why (for your PhD): Bridgework often shows up in assessment redesign; you need a vocabulary to describe variants and tradeoffs.
Key refs/resources: Linked to re-timing and re-authoring practices in your construct.

Topic: Academic integrity & detection/proctoring: limits and unintended effects
Action/Deliverable: Summarize major arguments: false positives, equity, surveillance, trust; note what your study will/won’t claim.
Why (for your PhD): Prevents the project from being pulled into tech-deterministic debates; keeps focus on legitimacy and time.
Key refs/resources: Proposal notes contested terrain around AI proctoring/detection/feedback.

Topic: Digital transformation theory basics (beyond adoption): sociotechnical change, organizing, capabilities
Action/Deliverable: Write a short 'DT positioning' paragraph for your paper: how your study extends DT accounts by adding temporal legitimacy.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal critiques DT accounts that assume speed is beneficial; you need to position clearly in IS/DT literature.
Evidence of completion: Revised positioning paragraph + candidate target journals list
Key refs/resources: Proposal identifies a gap: speed treated as beneficial; legitimacy assumed to follow.

Topic: Dynamic capabilities vs sociomaterial/process views (when each helps)
Action/Deliverable: Make a compare-contrast table: what each explains, where it fits your argument, and avoid mixing logics.
Why (for your PhD): You’ve used Dynamic Capabilities & Sociotechnical Systems in your index work; align that experience with your new theorizing choices.
Key refs/resources: DTI deck uses Dynamic Capabilities and Sociotechnical Systems as theory anchors.

Topic: Process research & longitudinal case study design
Action/Deliverable: Design note: case selection logic, number of cases, access strategy, and what counts as a 'flashpoint event'.
Why (for your PhD): Your study is explicitly longitudinal multi-case process; design quality is judged hard in management journals.
Key refs/resources: Proposal: longitudinal multi-case process study (3–5 universities) and identify flashpoint events.

Topic: Interviewing multiple audiences (students, faculty, admins, parents/employers)
Action/Deliverable: Draft 3 tailored interview guides + recruitment scripts + consent language.
Why (for your PhD): Multi-audience legitimacy is central; you need instruments that elicit differences without leading respondents.
Key refs/resources: Proposal lists interviews across faculty/students/admins and (where feasible) parents/employers.

Topic: Observation of classrooms/assessment as temporal practice
Action/Deliverable: Create an observation protocol focusing on pacing, deadlines, AI use moments, feedback loops, authoring negotiations.
Why (for your PhD): Temporal structuring requires you to 'see time' in practice; observation protocol is the bridge.
Key refs/resources: Proposal includes classroom & assessment observations (time and interaction enacted).

Topic: Document & artifact analysis (policies, rubrics, integrity cases)
Action/Deliverable: Set up a document coding scheme aligned to re-timing/re-authoring/re-legitimating.
Why (for your PhD): Artifacts are a major data source and often contain explicit legitimacy language.
Key refs/resources: Proposal lists institutional artifacts as a key data source.

Topic: Abductive analysis (iterate between data and theory)
Action/Deliverable: Create an analysis workflow: initial coding → memos → theoretical sampling → second-cycle coding; define memo types.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal commits to abductive analysis; you need a repeatable workflow to avoid getting lost in data.
Key refs/resources: Proposal: abductive analysis iterating between data and theory.

Topic: Temporal data strategies (event sequencing, narratives, visual maps)
Action/Deliverable: Practice with a small dataset: build a timeline, identify episodes, and link to legitimacy judgments.
Why (for your PhD): Your theory is about time; using explicit temporal analytic techniques strengthens the paper.
Key refs/resources: Aligned with temporal structuring lens.

Topic: Longitudinal survey design (waves, panel retention, measurement invariance)
Action/Deliverable: Draft survey wave plan: timing, constructs, attention checks, and invariance strategy across audiences.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal includes a longitudinal survey with students/staff/(employers) and panel techniques; design errors are costly.
Key refs/resources: Proposal outlines longitudinal survey across stakeholder groups and panel/regression analysis.

Topic: Scale development & validation (deep dive)
Action/Deliverable: Extend your psychometric pipeline: item response theory basics, reliability, validity types, CFA/SEM reporting standards.
Why (for your PhD): You already have a pipeline from index work; deepen to PhD-level rigor for publication.
Evidence of completion: Measurement model report template + simulated example
Key refs/resources: DTI deck mentions IRT, EFA/CFA, internal consistency, ICC/rWG, invariance.

Topic: Panel / longitudinal regression basics
Action/Deliverable: Learn fixed/random effects intuition, clustered SE, and basic panel diagnostics; write an analysis plan for your variables.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal mentions regression and panel-based techniques; you need to know what claims are defensible (you already state non-causal).
Key refs/resources: Proposal: panel/regression to explore associations (not causal).

Topic: Multilevel data (students nested in courses/universities) — when you need it
Action/Deliverable: Decide whether your survey requires multilevel modeling and what minimum sample structure is needed.
Why (for your PhD): HE data often nests; ignoring this can bias inference. You need an explicit choice.
Key refs/resources: Relevant given multi-case universities and multiple stakeholder groups.

Topic: Visualization & reporting (tables/figures for management journals)
Action/Deliverable: Create templates for descriptive stats, construct validity tables, and key plots.
Why (for your PhD): Speeds up paper writing later and reduces last-minute formatting stress.
Key refs/resources: Journal style guides (AMJ/OS/ISR etc).

Topic: Qual–quant triangulation strategy
Action/Deliverable: Write a 1–2 page integration plan: which constructs are shared, how survey informs case comparisons, and what 'convergence' looks like.
Why (for your PhD): Your survey is meant to triangulate process analysis; reviewers will ask how the strands talk to each other.
Evidence of completion: Integration memo + joint display table skeleton
Key refs/resources: Proposal explicitly says the quant strand triangulates and strengthens theory development.

Topic: Case comparison logic (cross-case analysis)
Action/Deliverable: Define cross-case dimensions (e.g., policy stance, assessment design intensity, AI governance maturity) and how they relate to outcomes.
Why (for your PhD): Needed to explain variation: when institutions become 'fast but hollow' vs 'durable bridges'.
Key refs/resources: Proposal aims to explain when outcomes differ across cases.

Topic: Research ethics in HE (student privacy, power asymmetry, AI disclosure)
Action/Deliverable: Draft ethics protocol: consent, anonymity, data minimization, handling integrity cases, and AI-use disclosure rules for participants.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal flags these as core ethical concerns; ethics approval can be a schedule bottleneck.
Key refs/resources: Proposal notes privacy, disclosure, and power asymmetries.

Topic: Project management: year-by-year plan & weekly system
Action/Deliverable: Translate your proposal timetable into a weekly rhythm: reading, writing, data, analysis; set review cycles.
Why (for your PhD): Temporal structuring applies to your own PhD too—this keeps momentum without burnout.
Key refs/resources: Proposal includes a year 1–3 timetable outline.

Topic: Target journals & paper roadmap (1–3 papers)
Action/Deliverable: Choose 1 primary outlet for the main theory paper + a methods/measurement or education-focused outlet; outline paper packages.
Why (for your PhD): Helps you read with purpose and collect data that fits the genre expectations.
Key refs/resources: Align with your stated mid-range theory goal.

Topic: Translate theory to guidance (policy makers, QA bodies, employers)
Action/Deliverable: Draft an 'impact brief' outline: what universities should do during AI flashpoints; what evidence supports it.
Why (for your PhD): Your proposal targets societal contribution and guidance on what credentials certify; impact writing is a separate skill.
Key refs/resources: Proposal states societal contribution re: what degrees certify in AI-saturated world.
